stream_context.summary: Kaze works on two parallel tasks: a new Star-Select screen (menu) with Biobak’s art and a hazardous oil-wave block for the Dino Dino Domain course. He also reports a 5 % global render-time gain after rewriting culling and shadow handling in his custom engine.

development_findings.summary: Fixed Mario 64’s faulty culling math (hard-coded 45° FOV) and moved both culling radius and shadow data into the object itself, saving two RAM iterations and roughly 600 µs per frame (~5 % FPS gain).
development_findings.quote: I went from like 44 FPS to 46 and I put the culling into the object itself, not the geo layout… that saved like 600 microseconds.

development_findings.summary: The new engine now makes it trivial to give every object shadows; enemies have never had shadows before because Fast64 made it hard.
development_findings.quote: With my new engine it will be very easy to add them everywhere.

development_findings.summary: Star-Select menu is being rebuilt: scrolling sky backdrop, separate render function per course, 60 FPS, larger text with new kerning routine, and animated entrance for logo/stars.
development_findings.quote: Maybe, instead of one geolayout per thing, we'll have one render function per thing and the render function is what decides the geolayout.

development_findings.summary: Biobak’s Blender mock-ups are imported; Kaze writes code to tile the background and keep text / stars centred, fixing kerning offsets and widescreen issues.
Implemented a generic fade-out & respawn system for falling into oil: stores last ‘safe’ triangle whose edge distance exceeds a threshold, resets Mario and camera without disorienting snap.
development_findings.quote: This is the least disorienting way… it always shows exactly where you just died.

development_findings.summary: ChatGPT was used to generate the edge-distance algorithm, drastically speeding implementation.
development_findings.quote: You guys have no idea how hard that would have been to program by myself, and this is why I like ChatGPT.

development_findings.summary: Planned oil-wave (Blargg) hazard will physically push and damage Mario; visual wave mesh being prototyped in Blender.
Overall project status: about 70 % complete; 4½ courses remain.
development_findings.quote: We're missing like four and a half courses, so we're like over 70 % done at this point.

development_findings.summary: Consideration of overlay ‘decal Mario’ model to show temporary effects (e.g., oil stains) without touching main rig.
Not supporting N64 Rumble Pak; performance benchmarks temporarily remove certain effects for accuracy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze values single-button, immediate controls and dislikes exposing camera’s 8-direction grid unless level design requires it.
context_findings.quote: I want to stick to the one button one output philosophy.

context_findings.summary: Shows excitement over technical wins and frustration when videos were mis-scheduled, reducing views.
context_findings.quote: I accidentally scheduled two videos… that's why it's getting less views than it should.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy on internet haters: do not engage because retaliation is easier than protection; a reflection on personal safety.
context_findings.quote: If you have someone who really hates you, you should not engage with them, because it is so easy to just destroy someone.

context_findings.summary: Strong stance that Blueprints are for asset tweaks, not real programming; advocates C++ for performance and maintainability.
context_findings.quote: Programming in Blueprints… is gonna be slower, less performant, take longer, be more limited.

context_findings.summary: Mentions living by the sea for 25 years and taking Zeina to a seal rescue; brief personal anecdote.

biobak.summary: Provides new Star-Select backgrounds, combiner settings, and layout ideas; collaborates live on placement, tiling, and animation.
biobak.quote: Look at this—how cool is that… this would be really cool, I think.

key_stories.title: Culling Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: While profiling, Kaze discovers Mario 64’s original culling assumed a 45° FOV and applied arbitrary offsets. By rewriting it and embedding culling and shadow data inside each object, he shaves ~600 µs per frame, gaining 2–5 FPS.
key_stories.challenge: Framerate hovered around 44 FPS and enemies still lacked shadows.
key_stories.process: Analyzed Nintendo’s maths, rewrote FOV test, relocated data to object struct, removed two RAM passes.
key_stories.outcome: Engine now runs ~46 FPS and is easier to add universal shadows.
key_stories.key_quote: Culling in Mario 64 was fucked… fixing it saved like 600 microseconds.

key_stories.title: Star-Select Reinvention
key_stories.summary: Biobak’s updated art inspires Kaze to scrap the old ‘boring’ Star-Select. Together they import new assets, write scrolling tiling code, correct kerning, and keep it 60 FPS.
key_stories.challenge: Original menu looked static and mis-centred.
key_stories.process: Iterative Blender exports, geolayout refactor into render functions, background tiling, text scaling, and camera tests.
key_stories.outcome: Dynamic, widescreen-friendly menu nearly finished; one more course version pending.
key_stories.key_quote: I really like it… imagine entering this level for the first time and you see this.

key_stories.title: Safe Respawn in Oil Waves
key_stories.summary: Designing Dino Dino Domain’s oil sea required a fair, non-random respawn. Kaze uses ChatGPT to code a triangle-edge distance test, stores last safe position, and resets Mario with minimal camera jank.
key_stories.challenge: Avoid spawning Mario inside geometry or letting players sequence-break by falling.
key_stories.process: Generated maths via ChatGPT, integrated into update loop, tuned camera behaviour and damage timing.
key_stories.outcome: Reliable fade-out and respawn that shows the exact death spot; still tweaking damage delay and sound.
key_stories.key_quote: This is the least disorienting way… it always shows exactly where you just died.
